https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2108670 This fits 1" Spaced pegboard holes. It is a press fit. I currently use them in my kitchen to hold various tools. Put two together to hold a cellphone or tablet. I have not tested it to failure. If you want to do some testing, please add a comment.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%
Do not allow the pegs to curl up from the print bed too much. Some warping is ok, but gross deformation will render them useless.

description.text:
This is a snack dispenser perfect for peanuts or m&m's. A jar full of your favorite snack sits upside down on top of the dispenser body.  Hold your hand below the hole and turn the knob to receive your snack. 
This design is based on a wooden version that belonged to my grandparents.
12/28/2016 update:  I have never printed this, but now that I have a good printer, I will be printing it and modifying parts to fit properly, if needed.

author: willsmur

description.text:
From the fantastic Heroine's Quest: The Herald of Ragnarok, an RPG/adventure game hybrid from Crystal Shard. http://www.crystalshard.net/hq.htm
http://www.crystalshard.net/index.php This is one of the best AGS (Adventure Games Studio) games I've ever played, and their attention to Norse myth really won me over. If you played the old Sierra Quest For Glory games, I guarantee you'll love this. The game is 100% free, and a real labor of love for those who made it. You can get it on their site and on Steam, and if you liked it as much as I did, support them with a donation on PayPal. This simple dice game is featured within Heroine's Quest and I pretty much immediately decided that I needed a physical version. There's no better way to weather the Fimbulwinter than to hole up with some mead and roll some dice for 3D printed gold. The rules are pretty simple, so here goes: ----THE RULES----
As near as I can tell, the game can support upwards of two players. Each player has 3 dice and a stack of coins (print a bunch if you're feeling wealthy). To start the game, all players place their arms on the table (in a manly, viking fashion) and roll the dice so they are obscured from the other players. Starting with the first player (decide who that is somehow... probably via feats of strength or pain resistance) each player takes a turn. During a turn, you may bet a coin (placing it into a pile in the center of the table), bet two coins and and re-roll any selection of dice, or put two coins in and call (forcing all others to do so at that moment). Once you have chosen to call, the dice are revealed and the winner is decided. ----Scoring-----
The following combinations of rolls are ranked from best to worst. In the case of a tie, roll off with all of your dice until one viking...er, I mean player has won: 3 Ravens (Odinn)
3 Hammers (Thor)
3 Runes (Asgard)
1 of each (Midgard) From there, Ravens are worth more than Hammers, which are worth more than Runes, which are worth more than Blanks. You get the picture. The winner takes the pot and is congratulated for being the brawniest or something, and, should coins remain, the game continues. The base dice are 20mm (which is huge, chunky, and good for jotun and/or trolls) though I've included 16mm and 12mm versions which should be better for our puny human hands. Enjoy!
I printed mine at 50% infill with a layer height of .2

This is the character "Monokuma" of the japanese animation & PSP game "Danganronpa".

TIPS: Lay it down on the printing platform seems to product cleaner result for dualstrusion

A parametric Cotton Reel constructed by mating two identical halves.  
The halves make it easy to retrofit to reprap rods without any disassembly (for a simple filament spool holder).
Also great for cable grommits, eg for closing up a hole in an enclosure or wall after you pass a terminated monitor cable through.

• Adjust the two heights and three diameters at the top of the SCAD file.
  • Print two identical half cotton reels
  • Mate the two halves together (easier while still warm off the printer). The 3D printer layers help it to all lock nicely.
  • If they are too hard to mate, increase the "S" shim value

Printable without support. This Dvarapala was scanned from Jakarta's National Museum (Museum Gajah). Dvarapala (Sanskrit) is a door or gate guardian often portrayed as warrior or fearsome asura giant, usually armed with a weapon, the most common is gadha mace. The statue of dvarapala is a widespread architectural element throughout the Hindu and Buddhist cultures, as well as in the areas influenced by them like Java. Full article:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dvarapala

A chassis and mounting system for a small rover/robot. The length is configurable based on the balsa wood shaft used as the backbone. Was used as the structure of a line-following robot. Plenty of zap-strap holes are included on the chassis for "neater" wiring.  
Two motors with the normal servo-esque form-factor may be mounted on the chassis; stand-off spacing on the chassis fits the hole-spacing of an arduino UNO. A spring-loaded battery case can be mounted below the chassis, fits a certain cellphone battery size (modelled to fit the one battery we happened to have on hand).  
Sensors and other circuits may be mounted to the balsa shaft. All parts included are printable without supports (though with a bit of bridging). The holes and captive-nut holes are sized for 4-40 screws/nuts + some extra room for printing margins.

My little child wanted some eggs to fill the basket we made from a kid magazine.
I modelled one in Blender. I started importing the svg shape of an egg that I found here I sliced using Cura, because Slic3r didn't give me as good support as I wanted. I printed them (4 at a time) in PLA using my ReprapPro Huxley.

This is a lid to house the switch and harness for my low extruder temp mod for the UP printer.

I've used a 13ohm resistor inline with the termperature probe, to trick the printer into thinking the temperature is higher than it actually is. I found 13 ohms drops the extruder temp to around 240 C. ( I found this a good compromise for most colours) Although it still shows 270 in software. The addition of a switch allows quick and easy changes from OEM to aftermarket filament.
The plugs are JST-XT. Update - I now recommend using a 10 ohm 1 watt resistor as the 13 ohm can drop the temperature a little too far when printing with Taulmans nylon. The 10 ohm will give around 250-255 C. I also now offer the patch lead for those who don't want to, or can't make their own. http://www.3dprintergear.com.au/UP_low_temp_filament_mod_p/templead.htm

title: MAX7219 led matrix module - Joiner Bars

description.text: If you are experimenting with the standard MAX7219 matrix modules, (pcb 32mm x 50mm approx), this is a simple joiner bar to daisy chain them together. You will need M3 x 8mm long screws and preferably M3 nyloc nuts so they don't come undone. The bar narrows to allow the soldered connections from the MAX7219 chip to be fully seated.
3D printed in PLA. 0.3mm Layer height.

author: ToScH

description.text: A retro rocket ship toy that can be printed with no support material!

Grab some coloured filament and print! Example printed with 10% infill (could print with no infill), with 3 perimeters and 3 solid layers. Designed to be printed with no support material! Final model is roughly 210mm tall. Enjoy! Print list:
Body x 1
Cone x 1
Boosters x 3
Exhaust x 2

comments.text: Great model, but some improvements are in order. The cone was not printing for me, it was having adhesion and curling problems, then I realized the overhang on the base and in the groove is quite a bit more than 45Â°. I increased the diameter of the base (the outer ring of the first layer) to 28.5mm as well as the innermost mesh of the recessed ring near the bottom of the cone until it looked like about a 45Â° overhang. Another issue is the booster pegs are about 9.5mm in diameter and the holes in the base are just under 9mm diam, so they don't fit without drilling out the holes a bit. Also, the tops of those peg holes are flat so you may get some sag inside if your printer doesn't do bridges really well. There's plenty of room to make them 45Â° cones inside so there's no risk of that. If printing in PLA these tolerances are more important since PLA isn't as flexible.
comments.author: jeffwillden

title: Merex Direct Drive Extruder 1,75 or 3mm Filament

description.text:
Hi
I designed this extruder for my new Merlin Hotend. the extruder is designed so it can be printed in one part, using support structures.
but be careful. there a many very thin structures inside, so you need a really good setup to print this part in good quality. i used the merlin hotend with 0,2mm nozzle. every drive gear from 10 to 13mm diameter will fit just fine. You need some screws, springs etc -3X M3x20
-2x M4 threaded bolt 70mm
-2x M4 safety nuts
-1x M6 x20mm
-2x M4 wingnuts
-2x short 10mm springs
-1x M10 nut
-2x M4 x xx mm to connect the extruder to your x carriage (50mm hole distance)
1x 626ZZ ball bearing Note: this is a work in progress, so i may change some minor things. i really appreciate yor help and i will be thankful for your suggestions and tips to make this extruder better. Update 8.04.2014 Added the Thing Merex V2 1,75 for 1,75mm Filament
and slightly changed the design Update 20.04.2014 Added the Thing "Merex V2 1,75_2 for 1,75mm Filament. changes:
  • i changed the motormount holes. now you can slightly change the position of the merex extruder on your motor to get closer to the bearing or drive screw.
    • Update 21.04.2014 Added the thing "Merex V2_3mm_2 for 3mm filament.
  • Changed the motormount holes
    • Update 2.05.14 Test of the 1,75mm Merex Extruder with the Merlin Hotend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HJX_yAC_kTU Update 13.05.14 Added a new Thing "Merex V2 1,75 support" with selfmade support structures for best quality. With support you have much less problems, easy to remove

Build on a Protos V2 with Merlin Hotend 0,2mm Nozzle 0,125mm Layerheight,ABS 240ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ°C For the Merlin Hotend. You ll need to thread the Hole on the bottom to M10 so you can screw in the merlin hotend, then conter it with a M10 Nut. For other hotends, you will need an Adapter , J-Head etc.. Note:
  • you Must print this in ABS! The Merlin Hotend will get hot. the thermal barrier that gets screwed in the extruder will still get hot too around 60 to 80 ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ°C PLA will loose its stability at this temparature!

comments.text: What bearing are you using on the idler part? And is the M6x20 for that one?
comments.author: redkite

comments.text:
Hi
The M6x20 is the screw that holds the bearing in place. i forgot to put the bearing on the partslist. its a 626ZZ Bearing
comments.author: redkite

comments.text:
Hi, saw your extruder featured on the merlin hotend site, but does it also work with the MK8 drive gear with 1.75mm filament? As I prefer that one. Currently using a Bowden setup, but this extruder looks very good and might just be worth changing.
I also have the skills to create my own bowden 1.75mm extruder, however, it's ofcourse not always necessary to redesign something.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text:
Hi
The Mk8 Gear is only 9mm in outer diameter. i dont think that it will work with this extruder. i just put a 9mm gear on the cad model to see how it would look like. the main problem is, that the filament will get bend just above the lower hole and eventually get stuck or something. the other problem is that the idler that holds the bearing has only a few mm range to move in and will not reach the filament at all.
one way to use the extruder with this gear is to replace the 626zz bearing with a 627zz which has a bigger diameter (but 7mm inner diameter, so you will need a 7mm bolt and drill the 6mm hole to 7mm) and you have to drill the 1,75mm hole to 2 or perhaps 3mm to make sure the filament doesnt bend.
another possibility is to drill the holes for the nema17 motor bigger so you can move the motor with the gear closer to the filament itself.. maybe that will work best.
comments.author: Marinus

comments.text:
Okay, thanks, I will for now use my old bowden extruder, and see if I can change something based on your design, since I think it has a lot of good points in it.
Do you have movies of the extruder working?
comments.author: Reaching

comments.text: Hey. I have some movies of the extruder working, but havent uploaded it yet. i was planning to make a movie with the extruder working and a how to, to show everyone how to set up the extruder.. Will be availiable soon :)
comments.author: Marinus

comments.text:
Hi, just finished my year at the academy (next year is graduation year), so I have more time now. I might develop my own bowden extruder for the Merlin hotend, inspired by yours, but then it will be a 2-part extruder, split exactly down the middle so it's easy to print and can be printed in 2 runs for people with a currently unreliable extruder that often goes wrong (2 halves both printable on another time), and a separate idler still. I printed yours, but in PLA, and it is not flexible enough to withstand the bending.
Another pro with this 2-part extruder is that you can 'sandwich' the needed bearings in between the two parts, making is easy to assemble. The only thing I'm still not sure about is how I will handle different kind of filament gears. For now I will design it for the MK8 because it's what I have laying around and use myself (I actually have 2). It will feature a bearing on the far end of the stepper motor shaft so it doesn't wear out the stepper motor, this was also done in Airtrippers bowden extruder.
Are there any things you learned from your extruder design that might be crucial for extruder design?
comments.author: Reaching

comments.text: i am looking forward to see it works .
comments.author: treblasnirp
